channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Zelensky Makes Appearance From His Presidential Office
item.description: The Ukrainian leader, Volodymyr Zelensky, said in a video that he was not in hiding. Ukraine’s government claims to have shot down two Russian planes over Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian forces unleashed a vicious artillery attack on the southern Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv on Monday, hitting residential neighborhoods with rockets and sending streams of people fleeing.

item.title: With New Limits on Media, Putin Closes a Door on Russia’s ‘Openness’
item.description: The Russian leader is undoing the social freedoms introduced at the end of the Soviet Union, risking a return to total control and ideological isolation.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: An enormous screen on a hotel on the outskirts of Moscow last April displayed Vladimir V. Putin as he gave a speech to the nation.

item.title: Once Victims in Southeast Europe, Jews Come to Aid Fleeing Ukrainians
item.description: Today, as in the early 1900s, Jews are once again escaping violence in southeast Europe. But the context is radically different — cathartically so for the many Israelis who have come here to join the relief effort.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: Baltics, in Russia's Shadow, Demand Tougher Stance From West
item.description: “We have no illusions about Putin’s Russia anymore,” said one Baltic official in a meeting with the U.S. secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes

item.title: These Syrian Refugees Can't Stay in Denmark, but They Can't Go Home
item.description: Dozens of Syrian asylum seekers are stuck in limbo after the Danish authorities decided it was safe for them to go back home and stripped their residency permits.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Jasmina Nielsen
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Haitham Kurdi from Syria in the communal kitchen of the Kaershovedgaard deportation center in the town of Ikast, Denmark.

item.title: Xi and Putin’s 'No Limits' Bond Leaves China Few Options on Ukraine
item.description: Beijing aligned itself with Putin as Russia prepared to invade Ukraine. Now its efforts to edge away are constrained by leadership politics.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing on Feb. 4. In a joint statement, the leaders had vowed that their countries’ friendship had “no limits.”

item.title: Ukrainians Find That Relatives in Russia Don’t Believe It’s a War
item.description: Many Ukrainians are encountering a confounding and frustrating backlash from family members in Russia who have bought into the official Kremlin messaging.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photographing the debris of a building hit by missiles in Kyiv, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Hate for Putin’s Russia Consumes Ukraine
item.description: Much of the bitterness is directed at President Vladimir V. Putin, but Ukrainians also chastise ordinary Russians, calling them complicit.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral near Lviv on Sunday for a member of the Ukrainian Army who died while fighting Russian forces.

item.title: Italian City Tied to Russia by a Revered Saint Feels the Sting of War in Ukraine
item.description: The port of Bari holds relics venerated by Orthodox Christians throughout the former Soviet bloc. Today it is also home to a spillover of tensions from Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Nadia Shira Cohen
item.media:description: Praying for peace on Thursday at the Pontifical Basilica of St. Nicholas in Bari, Italy. The saint’s crypt is an important pilgrimage site for both Orthodox and Catholic Christians.

item.title: Amazon Rainforest May Be Approaching a Critical Tipping Point, Study Finds
item.description: The region is nearing a threshold beyond which its forests may be replaced by grasslands, with huge repercussions for biodiversity and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighting a fire in the Brazilian Amazon near Rio Pardo in 2019.

item.title: What Cities Is Russia Targeting in Ukraine?
item.description: About two-thirds of Ukraine’s population of 44 million people lived in cities before Russia’s invasion began. Now many urban areas are in the cross hairs of war.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleaning up debris after a residential building was hit by missiles in Kyiv in February.

item.title: ‘Falling Into Emptiness’: Ukrainian Families Feel the Pain of Separation
item.description: With most Ukrainian men legally prohibited from leaving Ukraine, the international border gates serve as a painful filter, splitting families as women and children move on.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees from Ukraine waiting for a bus on Sunday after crossing the Polish border at Medyka.

item.title: What Is a No-Fly Zone, and Why Is It So Contentious?
item.description: Enforcing a ban on aircraft could draw more countries into conflict against Russia and set off “a full-fledged war in Europe,” NATO’s leader has warned.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A billboard in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, calling on NATO to implement a no-fly zone over the country.

item.title: On Ukraine’s Border, Moldovans Wonder: Where Will Putin Stop?
item.description: Moldovans fear that Transnistria, a region run by Russia-backed separatists in eastern Moldova, might be the next target after Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the village of Molovata Noua, on the eastern side of the Dniester River.

item.title: In Burundi, the Drum Is a Revered Symbol of Unity. But Only Men Can Play.
item.description: Burundian drumming is a global phenomenon, featured in blockbuster movies and best-selling albums. But at home, authorities have restricted it to official functions — and banned women from performing.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Tchandrou Nitanga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Traditional Burundian drummers performing the royal drum dance.

item.title: How the West Marshaled a Stunning Show of Unity Against Russia
item.description: In a few frantic days, the West threw out the playbook it used for decades against the Kremlin and isolated Russia with unparalleled sanctions and penalties.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Katrin Bennhold and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on Friday in Mykolayiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: An intensifying humanitarian crisis in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Olga Korolyova, left, with a friend in the wrecked kitchen of her home in Mykolaiv, Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Is Seen in His Office for the First Time Since Invasion
item.description: The Ukrainian president told his people that he was not afraid or in hiding.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s president, Vlodymyr Zelensky, in Kyiv, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: As Russia’s Military Stumbles, Its Adversaries Take Note
item.description: President Vladimir Putin could still reduce cities in Ukraine to rubble, officials say. But European countries say they are not as intimidated by Russian ground forces as they were in the past.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Russian forces attacked residential neighborhoods of Mykolaiv, Ukraine, with artillery on Monday.

item.title: Humanitarian Crisis Worsens for Ukrainians Trapped in Russia’s Onslaught
item.description: Two weeks after the invasion began, tens of thousands of Ukrainians are without food, water or power. The Russians are increasingly resorting to indiscriminate shelling to help their forces advance.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer and Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Russian forces unleashed an artillery attack on the southern Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv on Monday, hitting residential neighborhoods with rockets and sending streams of people fleeing.

item.title: Biden Officials Weigh Russian Oil Ban as Gas Prices Soar
item.description: Global stocks dipped on Monday as U.S. officials discussed an oil cutoff, and gas prices hit a national average above $4, up more than 10 percent in a week.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Edward Wong and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas station in Miami Beach, Fla., last week. The cost of gasoline in the United States is approaching record levels.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: Risks to the brain
item.description: Covid-19 may cause tissue damage and loss of gray matter
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Whet Moser
item.media:description: Daily reported coronavirus cases in the United States, seven-day average.

item.title: Letter ‘Z,’ Symbol of Support for War, Spreads Across Russia
item.description: The letter, painted on Russian military vehicles, is suddenly ubiquitous in Russia, prompting talk of a Kremlin public relations campaign.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: The large Z on a billboard in St. Petersburg, Russia, is a symbol of the Russian military.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia escalates attacks on civilians
item.description: Plus new research warning of a drier Amazon and Xi’s relationship with Putin.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Russian forces unleashed a vicious artillery attack on the southern Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv on Monday.

item.title: Against C.D.C. Advice, Florida to Advise Against Covid Vaccines for Healthy Children
item.description: The C.D.C. has urged parents to get their eligible children vaccinated. “Covid-19 can make children very sick and cause children to be hospitalized,” the agency’s website says.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Alicia Devine/USA Today Network, via Reuters
item.media:description: Dr. Joseph A. Ladapo during a confirmation hearing last month.

item.title: 9/11 Suspect Is Returned to Saudi Arabia for Mental Health Care
item.description: Mohammed al-Qahtani had spent 20 years at Guantánamo Bay, where he was tortured so badly that he was ineligible to be tried at the war crimes court.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: The closed Camp X-Ray detention facility on Guantánamo Bay, where Mohammed al-Qahtani was subjected to brutal interrogation.

item.title: Truckers Protest Mandates on D.S. Beltway for a Second Day
item.description: Organizers of a convoy of vehicles protesting mask and vaccine mandates said they would drive another lap around the Beltway on Monday but did not intend to enter the capital.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Adam Bednar
item.media:credit: Jim Watson/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators prepare to depart the Hagerstown Speedway in Hagerstown, Md., on Monday.

item.title: Russia, Blocked From the Global Internet, Plunges Into Digital Isolation
item.description: Russian authorities and multinational companies have erected a digital barricade between the country and the West, erasing the last remnants of independent information online.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: The Kremlin in Moscow last month. Russians have been cut off from many Western internet services in a matter of days.

item.title: World’s Known Covid Death Toll Surpasses 6 Million
item.description: And stark vaccination disparities between countries remain, leaving the entire world vulnerable to the threat of a new, deadly variant.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Funeral home employees moving a body outside a makeshift Covid treatment area at a Hong Kong hospital last week.

item.title: A Quebec Restaurant Renames Poutine Dish as a Rebuke of Russia
item.description: Protest against the war in Ukraine has a new cultural front — food and drink names — as people across the world show solidarity with Ukraine by renaming or boycotting Russian-made products.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Poutine at Le Roy Jucep, in Quebec.

item.title: Ukrainians Repel Another Russian Assault on Mykolaiv, Officials Say
item.description: As the opposing armies fought outside the strategic port city near the Black Sea, residential areas within Mykolaiv came under intensifying Russian rocket and artillery fire.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Welcomes Justin Trudeau in Meeting After Having Had Covid
item.description: The queen received Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada at Windsor Castle on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II receives Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during an audience at Windsor Castle, on Monday.

item.title: Covid May Cause Changes in the Brain, New Study Finds
item.description: Brain scans before and after infection showed more loss of gray matter and tissue damage, mostly in areas related to smell, in people who had Covid than in those who did not.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: G. Douaud, Anderson Winkler and Saad Jbabdi, University of Oxford and NIH
item.media:description: A digital model of a human brain showing the parts of the brain that lost the most gray matter in the 401 Covid-infected participants in the study, in red-yellow.

item.title: Take a closer look at why American mask makers are going out of business.
item.dc:creator: Joe Nocera
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: DemeTech, a medical supply manufacturer in Miami, has laid off virtually all the employees it hired during the pandemic to make masks.

item.title: Ukraine Takes its Case Against Russia to the UN's Highest Court
item.description: The head of the Ukrainian delegation told the court that “millions are in danger” and accused Moscow of defiling the Genocide Convention.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Anton Korynevych, Ukraine’s permanent representative to Crimea, and Oksana Zolotaryova, the head of international law at Ukraine’s Foreign Affairs Ministry, spoke to reporters at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Monday.

item.title: IAEA Says an Agreement Over Nuclear Power Plants in Ukraine Is Urgently Needed
item.description: There has been no release of radiation, but problems have arisen at plants, said Rafael Mariano Grossi, the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, described the situation at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine last week.

item.title: Preventing This War
item.description: What might have done it?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier running toward an attack in Kyiv yesterday.

item.title: For Kotchakorn Voraakhom, Water and Landscape Do Mix
item.description: With climate change bringing harsher rains and rising waters, Kotchakorn Voraakhom designs landscapes to alleviate flooding and add greenery.
item.dc:creator: Sam Lubell

item.title: Rumiko Seya, REALs' President, Expands the Aid Group's Focus to Include Afghanistan
item.description: Rumiko Seya, president of REALs, is working to rescue women and families, including from Afghanistan, who had dreams before “it turned to darkness in one night.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Morelli

item.title: The Nun Reshaping the Role of Women Inside the Vatican
item.description: Sister Nathalie Becquart will play a prominent role at the Synod of Bishops next year as Pope Francis tries to encourage new voices in the hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: Celestine Bohlen
item.media:description: Sister Nathalie Becquart will serve as under secretary of the General Secretariat of the Synod of Bishops next year in Rome.

item.title: The Russian Journalist Zoya Svetova Continues Her Family's Dissident Past
item.description: Four generations of Zoya Svetova’s family have stood up to repression. The invasion of Ukraine has shaken them but also given them reasons for hope.
item.dc:creator: Alison Smale
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Vladimir Putin has cracked down on independent media, including TV Rain (Kanal Dozhd), which was headed by Zoya Svetova’s son.

item.title: Nadia Calviño, a Top Spanish Official, Wants More Women at the Decision-Making Table
item.description: Many of Spain’s leaders are female — evidence, Nadia Calviño says, of the “feminist society” that has emerged in her nation.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Dreifus

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A renewed attack by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: By Sunday, Ukrainian troops had driven Russian forces back from the city limits, for now halting their advance along the Black Sea. “We fight them day and night; we don’t let them sleep,” one general said.

item.title: Russia Keeps Up Attack, Again Halting Evacuation of Ukrainian Port City
item.description: An encircled Mariupol faced intense shelling, while Russian forces kept up their slow advance on Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Steven Erlanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Proud Band of Ukrainian Troops Holds Russian Assault at Bay — for Now
item.description: “Few expected such strength from our people,” said a Ukrainian colonel whose soldiers have repelled a Russian attack on the port city of Mykolaiv for three days.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: The burned husk of a Russian military vehicle near Mykolaiv, Ukraine, a critical port where Ukrainian forces have stymied a Russian advance.

item.title: Ukrainian Family’s Dash for Safety Ends in Death
item.description: Russian forces hit a bridge being used by civilians evacuating the fighting in Ukraine. Four people were killed.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wounded man was placed on a stretcher after being shot on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russian Forces Attack Evacuees
item.description: Plus China’s new economic plan and updates on an attack on a Pakistani mosque.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier runs to check on a family after a mortar round landed near a steady stream of Ukrainian civilians trying to make their way out of the village of Irpen.

item.title: As Women’s Marches Gain Steam in Pakistan, Conservatives Grow Alarmed
item.description: What began in 2018 as a single march for International Women’s Day has become an annual event in multiple cities. Opposition is rising, and threats are, too.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: The Aurat March — Urdu for “women’s march” — last year in Karachi, Pakistan. Since 2018, it has been held every year on March 8, International Women’s Day.

item.title: What Is NATO and Which Countries Are Members?
item.description: This Western mutual-defense alliance, which sees an attack on one member as an attack on all, is central to the war in Ukraine, even though Ukraine is not a member.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Romanian soldiers at a military air base used by the NATO Response Force in Mihail Kogalniceanu, near the Black Sea in Romania, on Sunday.

item.title: Pressed About Putin, Russian Conductor Quits Bolshoi and French Posts
item.description: The Bolshoi music director, Tugan Sokhiev, said he was “asked to choose one cultural tradition” over another and denounce President Putin for invading Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: The conductor Tugan Sokhiev faced demands from French officials that he clarify his position on Russia’s war in Ukraine before his next appearance with the Orchestre National du Capitole de Toulouse later this month.

item.title: Rubio, U.S. Lawmakers Are Largely Opposed to No-Fly Zone Over Ukraine
item.description: Members of both parties said such a move would risk drawing the United States into a conflict with Russia, another nuclear power.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said on Sunday that imposing a no-fly zone over Ukraine could lead to “basically the beginning of World War III.”

item.title: Police Arrest More Than 3,000 People As Protests Grow Across Russia
item.description: An activist group that tracks protests found demonstrations in nearly 50 cities on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian police officers detained a participant at a rally on Sunday against the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Protesters face the possibility of years in jail.

item.title: South Korea reports high turnout in early voting, but apologizes to coronavirus patients for a lack of preparation.
item.description: South Korea is experiencing a sharp spike in coronavirus cases, its worst wave of the pandemic, but is allowing infected voters to cast a ballot in the country’s contentious presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: People waiting in line to cast their early votes in South Korea’s presidential election at a polling station in Seoul on Saturday.

item.title: What We Know About Brittney Griner’s Detention in Russia
item.description: The W.N.B.A. star was stopped at an airport outside Moscow and accused of carrying hashish oil in her luggage. But much about the case remains unclear.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Brittney Griner of the United States during the 2020 Tokyo Olympics women’s basketball game against France in Saitama, Japan, in August.

item.title: In photos: Evacuation comes under fire near Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario

item.title: U.S. Is Exploring How to Send Soviet-Era Fighter Jets to Ukraine
item.description: The discussions follow President Volodymyr Zelensky’s impassioned plea to American legislators for assistance in obtaining more lethal military aid.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: A MIG-29 fighter jet of the Polish Air Force during an air show in 2013. The United States was discussing a plan with Poland to supply some of its Soviet-era aircraft to Ukraine.

item.title: At Least 4 Civilians Killed in Shelling by Russian Forces Near Kyiv
item.description: The attack in Irpin, west of the capital, suggested either direct targeting of evacuees or disregard for the risk of civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Policing Is Under Scrutiny as Murders Rise in the U.S.
item.description: Murders have spiked in the U.S., and experts say a mix of solutions works best.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Police officers in North Camden, N.J.

item.title: Here is the latest news about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: Mexico Soccer Riot Leaves 26 Injured, Officials Say
item.description: Videos posted on social media showed violent clashes between fans in a stadium in the central city of Querétaro on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Fans of rival teams at the stadium near Querétaro, Mexico, where bloody violence broke out on Saturday.

item.title: Russian Prisoners and Ukrainian Soldiers Describe Two Sides of the Conflict
item.description: The accounts painted a picture of a conflict consisting largely of ambushes, at least in northern Ukraine where the Russian forces are striving to encircle and capture the capital, Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian sniper prepares his rifle at a base in Kyiv on Saturday, as forces prepared to battle Russian troops entering the city.
